title: MasterChef Australia judge Melissa Leong slams trolls as she reveals struggle with online abuse
text:
She's just been announced as one of the new MasterChef judges.

But Melissa Leong has already been forced to hit back at online trolls, revealing the daily struggle she faces because of vile racist comments.

The 37-year-old food and travel writer, who is set to take part in next year's series, says she's not afraid to call out sexist behaviour.

New faces: Former MasterChef winner Andy Allen, food writer Melissa Leong and Scottish-born restaurateur Jock Zonfrillo (pictured) are the new judges on MasterChef Australia

As a first generation Singaporean Australian, Melissa grew up in southern Sydney but says she's often questioned about her Asian heritage.

Speaking to HuffPost Australia, Melissa said: 'As a woman of Asian origin, it’s a daily onslaught of fetishistic comments from strangers about your appearance and sexuality, and if I’m asked, ‘But where are you really from?’ one more time, I might explode.

'When you’re outgoing and you’re Asian and you’re a female, people go, "Oh that’s awesome, I’ve totally got yellow fever". Well that’s really disgusting.'

Insta-worthy: Melissa (pictured) is already hitting back at online trolls, revealing the daily struggle she faces because of vile racist comments

Popular: On social media, Melissa often shares glamorous selfies and snaps of mouth-watering food with her with 21.5k followers

Melissa reveals her experience with racist and sexist abuse is not just online as she's regularly approached by men who have fetishised her background.

But undeterred, Melissa is fighting back on social media, and has previously used her posts to respond to comments made about her.

She often shares glamorous selfies and snaps of mouth-watering food with her 21.5k followers.

The foodie is no stranger to being in front of cameras, having appeared as a judge on SBS's The Chefs' Line alongside Dan Hong and Mark Olive.

Questions: As a first generation Singaporean Australian, Melissa grew up in southern Sydney, but says she's often questioned about her Asian heritage

She also regularly appears on Justine Schofield's Everyday Gourmet and Matt Sinclair's The Cook's Pantry, both of which air on Channel 10.

Channel 10 confirmed Melissa as one of the new judges on Thursday alongside Scottish-born restaurateur Jock Zonfrillo and former MasterChef winner Andy Allen.

But soon after her confirmation, Melissa was forced to defend less than positive tweets she had previously made about the show.

Speaking during an interview on The Project, Melissa said she stands by her comments because, at the time, they were her honest thoughts.

Uh oh: New MasterChef judges Andy Allen, Melissa and Jock Zonfrillo (pictured) appeared on The Project where the food writer was forced to defend tweets she'd previously written about the show
